pageContext.claim: “We're working very, very hard on that. Opioid -- we're down 17 percent from last year. Who would have thought that?”
pageContext.analysis: A White House spokesman told CNN that Trump was referring to a 17 percent decline in monthly opioid prescriptions since Trump took office. As we have reported, opioid prescriptions have been declining for years, having reached a peak in 2010 or 2012, depending on what data set you use. The declines especially began to accelerate after the CDC in March 2016 issued new guidelines for prescribing opioids for chronic pain — 10 months before Trump took the oath of office.
